column2: officially the City of General Santos (Cebuano: Dakbayan sa Heneral Santos; Hiligaynon: Dakbanwa sang Heneral Santos; Maguindanao: Ingud nu Heneral Santos; Blaan: Banwe Dadiangas; Tboli: Benwu Dadiangas; Filipino: Lungsod ng Heneral Santos)
column3: abbreviated as GenSan
column4: is a 1st class highly urbanized city in Soccsksargen
column5: Philippines. According to the 2015 census

column1: Located on the island of Mindanao
column2: it is the southernmost and 15th-most populous city in the Philippines. It is the regional center for commerce and industry of the Soccsksargen region
column3: and is geographically located within the province of South Cotabato but administered independently of it.

column2: the city was named after Gen. Paulino Santos
column3: a former Commanding General of the Philippine Army and the settlement's leading pioneer.

column1: The nomadic Blaan people are the original inhabitants of General Santos
column2: and traces of their early settlement of the area are found in the city's place names
column3: which are derived from their vocabulary. Their name for the city
column5: is from the thorny Ziziphus spina-christi tree that was once abundant in the area and is now a protected species under Republic Act 8371 or the Indigenous Peoples Right Act of 2007. The B'laan tribe now lives alongside the city's new generation of settlers and other immigrants.

column1: Organized under the National Land Settlement Administration (NLSA) of the Commonwealth Government headed by President Manuel L. Quezon
column2: General Paulino Santos led the relocation of 62 Christian settlers from Luzon to the shores of Sarangani Bay aboard the steam ship “Basilan” of Compañia Maritima on February 27
column3: 1939. The 62 pioneers
column5: were the first large batch of settlers to land in the area with the mission to industriously cultivate the region. After this first influx of pioneers
column6: thousands more Christians from the Visayas and Luzon have subsequently moved into the area
column7: gradually driving some of the resident B'laan to the mountains

column2: the first formal settlement in the city was established in Alagao
column3: which is now known as Barangay Lagao. Lagao district was known then as the "Municipal District of Buayan" under the jurisdiction of the deputy governor of the Municipal District of Glan. Until it officially became an independent Municipal District of Buayan on October 1
column5: appointing Datu Sharif Zainal Abedin—an Arab mestizo married to a daughter of a very influential datu of lower Buayan—as the first district municipal mayor.

column2: the Municipal District of Buayan become one of the last frontiers between the combined American and Filipino forces and troops from the Empire of Japan. Retreating Imperial Japanese forces made Klaja Karsts Land their last ground for defence
column3: constructing round cement bunkers and tunnels. These bunkers can still be seen at Sitio Guadalupe; most of the tunnels
column5: have since been damaged and even destroyed by treasure hunters and land developers.

column1: === Renaming and elevation to city status ===
A year after the Philippines regained full sovereignty from the United States on July 4
column3: the Municipality of Buayan became a 4th class regular municipality by virtue of the Executive Order Number 82
column5: 1947 by President Manuel Roxas
column6: absorbing the Municipal District of Glan
column7: whose low income bracket at the time disqualified it for the honour. Dadiangas was the seat of government for the Municipality of Buayan electing Irineo Santiago as its first Municipal Mayor on a local election that was held on November 11
column8: 1947. Mayor Santiago was formally inducted on January 1
column11: the Municipality of Buayan was renamed General Santos as a tribute to the leading pioneer via Act No. 1107 authored by Congressman Luminog Mangelen of Cotabato Province.

column2: the municipality's economy experienced a boom under Mayor Lucio A. Velayo
column3: as several large agri-based and multinational firms such as Dole Philippines
column4: General Milling Corporation and UDAGRI expanded into the area. Although it was then qualified to become a fourth class city from being a municipality
column5: the residents rejected a move by Congressman Salipada Pendatun to convert the Municipality of Buayan into a city and to rename it ’’Rajah Buayan’’.

column3: the Municipality of General Santos was converted into a city upon the approval of Republic Act No. 5412
column4: authored by Congressman James L. Chiongbian. It was inaugurated on September 5 of that year
column5: with Antonio C. Acharon became the new city's first mayor. On September 5
column7: a decade after its inauguration as a chartered city
column8: GenSan was declared a highly urbanized city of South Cotabato.

column1: General Santos City lies at the southern part of the Philippines. It is located at 6°7'N 125°10'E latitude. The city is southeast of Manila
column2: southeast of Cebu and southwest of Davao.

column1: The city is bounded by municipalities of Sarangani Province
column3: and Maasim in the south. General Santos is likewise bounded by the South Cotabato municipality of Polomolok and Sarangani Province municipality of Malungon in the north
column4: and the municipality of T'boli in the west.

column1: General Santos City has a tropical wet and dry climate (Köppen climate classification). With an average annual rainfall of less than 1000 mm
column2: it is one of the driest places in the Philippines.

column1: General Santos City is politically subdivided into 26 barangays.
There are two major languages spoken in the city
column2: with Cebuano being widely spoken and being used by the local media outlets in the city (television
column3: radio
column5: followed by Hiligaynon
column6: which is used mainly by settlers who came from the provinces of South Cotabato
column9: as well as immigrants from the provinces of Negros Occidental
column10: Iloilo and Guimaras. Other languages spoken within the city include Blaan

column1: The predominant religion in the city is Christianity
column2: with the largest denomination being the Catholic Church
column3: comprising almost 90 percent of the population. About 9% of the population belongs to Islam

column1: The city's major economic activity is primarily anchored in two sectors namely the agro-industry and fishing industry.
Agro-industry: Endowed with rich volcanic soil
column2: ample and well distributed rainfall all throughout the year and a typhoon-free climate
column3: General Santos City produces export quality high valued crops such as corn
column5: pineapple
column7: banana and rice. It also yields quality exotic fruits
column8: vegetables and cut flowers. The city is also a top producer and exporter of quality livestock such as poultry
column10: and cattle. But with the continuing growth in population and economy in the passing of time
column11: a number of the city's agricultural lands have gradually been converted into built up areas in order to address the relatively growing need of dwelling and viable spaces.

column1: Fishing industry: General Santos City is the largest producer of sashimi-grade tuna in the Philippines. Thus
column3: it was nicknamed "Tuna Capital of the Philippines". GenSan also accounts for the second-largest daily total catch of fish in the country after Navotas City in the National Capital Region. Locals in the city boast that fishes and seafoods do not come fresher than what is found in their locality. The fishing industry in GenSan yields a total daily capacity of 750 metric tons of fish catch
column5: 800 workers. General Santos City is home to seven tuna processing plants. The Fishport Complex in Barangay Tambler has a 750 metres (2
column6: 460 ft) quay and a 300 metres (980 ft) wharf for 2
column7: 000 GT reefer carriers. The fishport is equipped with modern facilities that comply with international standards on fish catch handling.General Santos City registered 1
column8: 365 new medium to large enterprises in 2011. An aggregate investment involved is estimated PHP 1.202 billion. Top industry for new investment in 2011 was as follows: Hotel and Restaurant-31%; Wholesale & Retail Trade-20%; Repair of Motor Vehicles
column10: Real Estate & Renting Business Activities-17%; Other Community
column11: Social & Personal Services-8%; Financial Intermediation-5%; Manufacturing-5%; Fishing-3%; ICT-3 %

column2: there are 59 banks serving the city. This composed of 46 commercial banks
column3: 5 savings banks
column4: 7 rural banks and 1 cooperative bank. Aside from this
column5: there are 48 lending institutions as well as 49 pawnshops providing emergency loan assistance.

column1: General Santos City is the shopping capital of the Soccksargen region. Residents from nearby towns and provinces visit the city to do shopping and enjoy life and leisure activities. There are several huge shopping malls in the city
column2: notable ones are KCC Mall of Gensan
column3: SM City General Santos
column5: Gaisano Mall of GenSan
column8: and the newest addition to the city which is RD City Mall located at Barangay Mabuhay and Unitop Shopping Mall in Barangay Dadingas West. SM Savemore has two branches in the city and another branch will be built within the downtown area. There are also news about building an Ayala Mall and Puregold. These malls are home to both national and international brands of retail merchandises as well as restaurants and cafes. There are many merchandise and large groceries owned by local and foreign Chinese
column9: Taiwanese and Korean businessmen in the city.

column1: CommunicationModern and state-of-the-art communication facilities at par with global standards are readily available and are provided in General Santos City by major telecommunication companies in the country. These include voice
column3: internet and network solutions
column5: in both wired and mobile forms.

column1: GenSan and the whole of Soccsksargen can be reached by air
column3: or sea.

column1: Air TransportationThe General Santos International Airport is the largest airport in Mindanao. It has a 3
column2: 227-metre concrete runway capable of handling wide-bodied jets like Airbus A340 and Boeing 747. It was also called Rajah Buayan Airport in the 1990s
column3: and Tambler Airport in 2008
column4: before being renamed to its current name. Flights to and from Manila
column5: Iloilo
column6: and Cebu are currently being operated in the airport by Philippine Airlines and Cebu Pacific. General Santos International Airport is the second busiest airport in Mindanao and 9th busiest airport in the Philippines.

column1: The Makar Wharf is the main international sea port of the city and is one of the finest sea ports in the country. It is location in Barangay Labangal
column2: away from the central business district. With a 740 metres (2
column3: 430 ft) docking length and a 19 metres (62 ft) width
column4: the wharf can accommodate up to nine (9) ship berthing positions all at the same time. The port is replete with modern facilities such as container yards
column5: storage and weighing bridges.  Several shipping companies operate regular inter-island ferry service to and from other major ports in Luzon
column7: SuperFerry and Sulpicio Lines provide these inter-island shipping routes while numerous Indonesian shipping lines operate international ferry service between General Santos City and neighboring ports in Indonesia carrying both passenger and cargo loads.

column1: Land TransportationCommuting in and around General Santos City is a fast and convenient ride. More than 400 passenger buses
column2: public utility vans and jeepneys wield routes within the city and neighboring provinces like in Koronadal
column3: Cotabato
column5: Tacurong
column7: Cagayan de Oro and others.  Three-wheeled motorized cabs known as tricycles are the city's main mode of public transport and have been on the road since the pioneering times. Air-conditioned taxis also ply the city streets offering commuters a choice of a more comfortable mode of transportation.

column1: Maintained by the City Engineers' Office
column2: the city's major road networks are paved and endowed with safety road marks
column3: signs and signals to ensure a secure and efficient traffic flow within the city.  The Pan-Philippine Highway links the city by land to other major cities in Mindanao and to the rest of the country.

column1: The General Santos City Terminal—popularly known as Bulaong Terminal; located in Barangay Dadiangas North is the city's main integrated land transport terminal.  The terminal serves as the city's gateway for land travelers. Buses and other forms of public mass transportation—to and from various parts of Mindanao such as Koronadal
column3: Cotabato
column5: Kidapawan

column1: Majority of the city's power supply is being serviced by the second district of South Cotabato Electric Cooperative (SOCOTECO-II). The said power distributor acquires the majority of its power needs for the city's consumption from the National Transmission Corporation (TransCo) while other sources are drawn from various Independent Power Producers (IPP) from nearby power plants and barges.Water
Majority of the households and other entities in the city are provided and serviced with clean
column2: safe and potable water supply from deep well sources by General Santos City Water District (GSCWD).  Potable water sources in other far flung and remote parts of the city where cannot be reached by the local water utility service are being served by their individual Barangay Water And Sanitation systems.Waste management

column1: In a bid to achieve an efficient and sustainable management of non-hazardous waste the city produces every single day
column2: the finalization and construction of the city's waste water treatment facility is currently underway at the corner of P. Acharon and I. Santiago Boulevards. The said location is adjacent to the city public market and is the former site of the city's Fish Landing. The facility will include settling ponds and anaerobic reactors
column3: among others.Likewise is the finalization stage for the construction of a multi-million peso solid waste management and disposal system in Barangay Sinawal. The new and modern solid waste management facility will replace the existing city dumpsite in Barangay Siguel.

column2: a military task force has been formed to protect the city from terrorist attacks and other crime. Task Force GenSan is affiliated with the Philippine Army and headed by an army colonel. 8 Police Stations are built on each barangay to keep the safeness and a peaceful order in city. Agencies and Organizations are forming a good and peaceful will to group an order in a city.

column1: Aside from more than 50 Private Schools

column5: Mindanao State University - General Santos and  New Era University - General Santos Campus. It also houses colleges such as the Doña Lourdes Institute of Technology.

column3: Sapol
